title: extera
text: Everything extera revolves around ExTera object, serves template library encapsulated rendering methods. example, initialize ExTera empty template library calling new_engine() arguments. complicated directory system nested templates inheritance patterns - common situation web development, may find easier initialize ExTera specifying directory glob containing * wildcard indicate number subfolders template files. Suppose, example, website directory looks like : can generate new ExTera around directory like
code:
website <- file.path(tempdir(), "website") dir.create(website) dir.create(file.path(website, "posts")) writeLines( text = '

Hello {{ x }}. This is {{ y }}.

', con = file.path(website, "index.html") ) writeLines( text = "

About Me

{{ description }}

", con = file.path(website, "about-me.html") ) writeLines( text = '

{{ title }}

{{ paragraph }}

', con = file.path(website, "posts", "blog-template.html") ) cat( "website", list.files(website, recursive = TRUE), sep = "\n- " ) website - about-me.html - index.html - posts/blog-template.html tera <- new_engine(dir = file.path(website, "**/*.html")) tera #> ── ExTera ── #> Template library: #> • about-me.html #> • index.html #> • posts/blog-template.html

title: extera
text: tera templating engine offers lot additional functionality, like control flow data manipulation. following example shows construct -loop, add conditional statements, apply built-functions. Notice {% expression %} used signal expressions template. use dashes tells renderer remove white space ({%- expression %}) ({% expression -%}) expression.
code:
tera$add_string_templates( "star-wars" = '

{{ title }}

    {%- for person in people %} {%- if person.films is containing("A New Hope") %} {%- if person.species and person.species is containing("Human") %}
  1. {{ person.name }} ({{ person.homeworld }})
    2. {%- endif %} {%- endif %} {%- endfor %}
' ) starwars <- dplyr::starwars[c("name", "films", "homeworld", "species")] string <- tera$render_to_string( "star-wars", title = "Humans of A New Hope", people = starwars ) cat(string) #>

Humans of A New Hope

#>

    2. #>

    3. #>
  3. Leia Organa (Alderaan)
    4. #>

    5. #>

    6. #>

title: extera
text: -loop, may noticed used dot-indexing syntax, e.g., person.name. person list R, equivalent person[["name"]]. Internally, Rust crate tera represents context values serde_json::Value, can hold valid JSON structure. challenge extera bridge R objects Rust type. handle , extera takes pragmatic approach: context values serialized JSON string R using yyjsonr package passed across FFI boundary string, deserialized serde_json::Value Rust side. round-trip strings, delegates tricky R--JSON conversion well-tested library. yyjsonr also fast, overhead minor. one consequence worth knowing : data.frames column-major R, conversion JSON create row-major records. affects template syntax, especially loops like person people. person record holding data row data.frame. example, person.name return value name column specific row data.frame. may help see example looks like. applies filters used template .
code: starwars[["in_a_new_hope"]] <- sapply(   starwars[["films"]],   \(x) "A New Hope" %in% x )  starwars <- subset(   starwars,   in_a_new_hope & !is.na(species) & species == "Human",   select = c(name, homeworld) )  json_str <- yyjsonr::write_json_str(   list(     title = "Humans of A New Hope",     people = starwars   ),   auto_unbox = TRUE,   pretty = TRUE )  cat(json_str) #> { #>   "title": "Humans of A New Hope", #>   "people": [ #>     { #>       "name": "Luke Skywalker", #>       "homeworld": "Tatooine" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Darth Vader", #>       "homeworld": "Tatooine" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Leia Organa", #>       "homeworld": "Alderaan" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Owen Lars", #>       "homeworld": "Tatooine" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Beru Whitesun Lars", #>       "homeworld": "Tatooine" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Biggs Darklighter", #>       "homeworld": "Tatooine" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Obi-Wan Kenobi", #>       "homeworld": "Stewjon" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Wilhuff Tarkin", #>       "homeworld": "Eriadu" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Han Solo", #>       "homeworld": "Corellia" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Wedge Antilles", #>       "homeworld": "Corellia" #>     }, #>     { #>       "name": "Raymus Antilles", #>       "homeworld": "Alderaan" #>     } #>   ] #> }

title: extera
text: Templates can inherit content one two ways, either using include , complicated inheritance, extends. extension mechanism little involved, requiring specify content blocks content child document injected. following example, define single block called content base parent template specify includes child template.
code:
tera$add_string_templates( "index.html" = '

Hello {{ x }}. This is {{ y }}.

{% include "posts/blog-template.html" -%}
' ) string <- tera$render_to_string( "index.html", x = "world", y = "ExTera", title = "My blog post", paragraph = "The Book of Bokonon tells us..." ) cat(string) #>

Hello world. This is ExTera.

#>
#> #>

My blog post

#>

The Book of Bokonon tells us...

#> #>
base_html <- '
{% block content %} {% endblock content %}
' child_html <- '{% extends "base.html" %} {%- block content -%}

{{ title }}

{{ paragraph }}

{%- endblock content -%}' tera$add_string_templates( "base.html" = base_html, "child.html" = child_html ) string <- tera$render_to_string( "child.html", title = "Index", paragraph = "Welcome to my homepage." ) cat(string) #> #>
#>

Index

#>

Welcome to my homepage.

#>
#>

Hello {{ x }}. This is {{ y }}.

', "hello-world.html" = '

Hello {{ x }}. This is {{ y }}.

' ) # not recognized as html tera$render_to_string( "hello-world", x = "&world", y = "an apostrophe, '" ) #> [1] "

Hello &world. This is an apostrophe, '.

" # html tera$render_to_string( "hello-world.html", x = "&world", y = "an apostrophe, '" ) #> [1] "

Hello &world. This is an apostrophe, '.

" # turn off autoescape tera$autoescape_off() #> ✔ Autoescaping is now off! tera$render_to_string( "hello-world.html", x = "&world", y = "an apostrophe, '" ) #> [1] "

Hello &world. This is an apostrophe, '.

Users mainly interact ExTera R6 object, serves template library encapsulated methods rendering templates. render template, users supply dataset known context, consists variable names values. Template syntax supports additional logic, including built-filters, tests, functions, well loops, conditions, inheritance. Documentation tera's templating syntax can found https://keats.github.io/tera/docs/.
